title: Prime Gaming (Easy Version)
statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, m≤2m≤2. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

A valid configuration is defined as an arrangement of nn piles of stones such that:

Given a valid configuration of nn piles of stones, some indices from 11 to nn are marked as good. Alice and Bob start playing a game taking n−1n−1 turns alternately with Alice going first. In each turn, they have to perform the following operation:

Note that after performing the operation once, the number of piles decreases by 11 and the remaining piles are re-indexed. The game will end when there is only one pile left. It is guaranteed that the index 11 is always good.

Let xx denote the number of stones in the final remaining pile. Alice wants to maximize xx, whereas Bob wants to minimize it. Both Alice and Bob play optimally.

Find the sum of xx over all the possible valid configurations modulo 109+7109+7.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers nn (1≤n≤201≤n≤20) and mm (1≤m≤21≤m≤2) — the number of piles and the upper bound on the number of stones in a pile.

The second line of each testcase contains a single integer kk (1≤k≤n1≤k≤n) — the number of indices marked as good.

The third line of each testcase contains kk integers c1,c2,…,ckc1,c2,…,ck (1=c1<c2<…<ck≤n1=c1<c2<…<ck≤n) — the good indices. It is guaranteed that 11 is always a good index (i.e. c1=1c1=1).

It is guaranteed that the sum of 2n2n over all test cases does not exceed 220220.

It is guaranteed that the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 106106.
outputSpecHtml: For each testcase, print a single integer — the sum of xx over all the possible valid configurations modulo 109+7109+7.
noteHtml:
For the first test case, the valid configurations are: [1,1][1,1], [1,2][1,2], [2,1][2,1], [2,2][2,2].

As there are only 22 piles of stones, Alice can only choose the first pile and remove it. Thus, the sum of xx is equal to 1+1+2+2=61+1+2+2=6.

For the second test case, the final pile is always 11.
